facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 598 of 1961 arises out of execution proceedings in execution of a decree dated March 7, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, presented on a certificate granted by the High Court of Andhra Pradesh, arises out of execution proceedings in execution of a decree dated March 7, 1938.

facts.text: Kudapa Subbanna, plaintiff No. 2 and respondent No. 1, was held entitled to the properties mentioned in Schedules A and C and to 1/24ths share in the properties mentioned in Schedule B.

anchor.surface_text: Kudapa Subbanna, plaintiff No. 2 and respondent No. 1 here, was held entitled to the properties mentioned in Schedules A and C and to 1/24ths share in the properties mentioned in Schedule B attached to the plaint.

facts.text: Possession over the properties in Schedules A and C was delivered to the decree-holder on February 17, 18 and 20, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: Possession over the properties in Schedules A and C was delivered to the decree-holder on February 17, 18 and 20, 1943.

facts.text: On June 23, 1945, the decree-holder filed I.A 558 of 1949 to revive and continue the earlier I.A. 429 of 1940 which had been struck off on September 25, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: On June 23, 1945, the decree-holder filed I.A 558 of 1949 to revive and companytinue the earlier I.A. 429 of 1940 which had been presented for the ascertainment of future profits and was struck off on September 25, 1944.

facts.text: On July 28, 1948, the Subordinate Judge decreed the mesne profits and interest thereon for the period from 1926-27 to 1942-43 with respect to the A and C schedule properties. The amount decreed was Rs. 17,883-8-3 including Rs. 10,790/- for mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: On July 28, 1948, the Subordinate Judge decreed the mesne profits and interest thereon for the period from 1926-27 to 1942-43 with respect to the A and C schedule properties. The amount decreed was Rs. 17,883-8-3 including Rs. 10,790/- for mesne profits.

facts.text: On April 22, 1949, Chitturi Subbanna, 1st defendant, appealed to the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: On April 22, 1949, Chitturi Subbanna, 1st defendant, appealed to the High Court.

facts.text: The decree-holder filed cross-objections and claimed Rs. 19,000/- more stating that the amount of mesne profits actually due to him would be about Rs. 45,000/- but he confined his claim to Rs. 19,000/- only.

anchor.surface_text: The decree-holder filed cross- objections and claimed Rs. 19,000/- more stating that the amount of mesne profits actually due to him would be about Rs. 45,0001- but he companyfined his claim to Rs. 19,000/- only.

facts.text: On September 13, 1958, the High Court dismissed the appeal, but allowed the cross-objection, increasing the amount of mesne profits decreed by the Subordinate Judge with respect to the A and C schedule properties to Rs. 17,242-12-0.

anchor.surface_text: On September 13, 1958, the High Court dismissed the appeal, but allowed the cross-objection, the result of which was that the amount of mesne profits decreed by the Subordinate Judge with respect to the A and C schedule properties was increased very substantially. The amount decreed for mesne profits was raised to Rs. 17,242-12-0

facts.text: Chitturi Subbanna obtained leave from the High Court to appeal to this Court as the decree was one of variance and the value exceeded Rs. 10,000/-

anchor.surface_text: Chitturi Subbanna then obtained leave from the High Court to appeal to this Court as the decree of the High Court was one of variance and the value of the subject matter in dispute was over Rs. 10,000/-

facts.text: The suit was instituted in the year 1926.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal from the judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh which arose out of a suit for pos- session and mesne profits instituted in the year 1926.

facts.text: The suit was dismissed by the trial court but on appeal the High Court of Madras passed a decree on March 7, 1938 in favour of the second plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was dismissed by the trial companyrt but on appeal the High Court of Madras passed a decree therein in favour of the second plaintiff who is the first respondent before us, on March 7, 1938.

facts.text: The High Court decree directed the lower court to make an enquiry as to the mesne profits from the date of the institution of the suit up to the date of delivery of possession to the second plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court made the following provision with respect to the claim for mesne profits that the lower companyrt do make an enquiry as to the mesne profits from the date of the institution of the suit and pass a final decree for payment of the amount that may be found due up to the date of delivery of possession to the second plaintiff.

facts.text: No further appeal was taken against the preliminary decree of March 7, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: No further appeal was taken by the first respondent, who is the appellant before us, against whom the decree was passed.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 obtained delivery of possession of some property in 1943 and another item on January 15, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 obtained delivery of possession of some of the property with respect to which his claim had succeeded in the year 1943 and of another item of property on January 1.5, 1948.

facts.text: Commissioner was appointed for enquiry into mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: On an application preferred by respondent No. 1 a Commis- sioner was appointed by the companyrt of first instance for making an enquiry into mesne profits.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge passed final decree for certain amount after considering Commissioner's report.

anchor.surface_text: After companysidering that report the companyrt passed final decree for a certain amount in favour of respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Appellant did not raise ground in memo of appeal that mesne profits could not be awarded beyond three years from preliminary decree.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, however, did number raise any ground in his memo of appeal to the effect that mesne profits companyld number be awarded for a period in excess of three years from the passing of the preliminary decree.

facts.text: It was conceded before the Commissioner and Subordinate Judge that accounts could be taken up to 1943 for A and C schedules and up to 1946 for B schedule.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it was companyceded before the Commissioner, as also the Subordinate Judge, that accounts can be taken up to the year 1943 in respect of the properties described in Schedules A and C to the plaint and up to 1946 in respect of properties described hi Schedule B to the plaint.

facts.text: High Court of Andhra Pradesh dismissed appeal and allowed cross-objection on September 13, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 13, 1958, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Appeal Suit No. 736 of 1952.

facts.text: Commissioner conducted enquiry about mesne profits from August 29, 1946 till December 4, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner companyducted the enquiry about mesne profits from August 29, 1946 till December 4, 1947.

facts.text: Mesne profits for B-schedule properties up to 1946 are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: He also decreed mesne profits with respect to the B-schedule properties upto 1946. They are number in dispute number.

facts.text: High Court disallowed appellant's prayer to raise additional ground on O.20 r.12 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: Chitturi Subbanna, appellant, applied to the High Court for permission to raise an additional ground of appeal to the effect that the trial Court was number entitled to grant mesne profits for more than 3 years from the date of the decree of the High Court. facts.text: Supreme Court holds that mesne profits cannot be awarded beyond three years from March 7, 1938 decree.

anchor.surface_text: the decree-holder in this case cannot get mesne profits for the period subsequent to March 7, 1941 when the three year period from the date of the High Court decree expired.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, case remanded to High Court for fresh determination of quantum of mesne profits up to March 7, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal with companyts of this Court, set aside the decree of the Court below and remand the case to the High Court to determine afresh the quantum of mesne profits up to March 7, 1941

issues.text: whether the direction in the preliminary decree operates as res judicata

anchor.surface_text: The direction in the preliminary decree cannot operate, in terms of s. 97 C.P.C. or on general principles, as res judicata for the simple reason, as stated earlier, that the direction is not based on the decision of any matter in controversy between the parties

holdings.text: The High Court was in error in not allowing the appellant to raise the additional ground of appeal based on O.20 r.12 CPC as it was a pure question of law.

anchor.surface_text: It is urged before us for the appellant that the High Court was in error in not allowing the appellant to have raised the objection based on the provisions of O .20, r. 12, C.P.C. We agree with this contention. The question sought to be raised was a pure question of law

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pure question of law not dependent on facts can be raised in first appellate court; High Court discretion improperly exercised as reasons given were not good.

holdings.text: Mesne profits cannot be awarded for a period subsequent to the expiry of three years from the date of the preliminary decree i.e., beyond March 7, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was in error in not allowing the appellant to urge this additional ground before it. The main point for determination in this appeal is whether mesne profits could be awarded to the decree-holder for a period subsequent to the expiry of three years from the date of the High Courts decree, i.e., subsequent to March 7, 1941.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Decree directing inquiry up to delivery of possession must be construed in conformity with O.20 r.12 limiting to three years or possession whichever earlier; supported by precedents like Girish Chunder.

holdings.text: Provisions of s.97 CPC do not preclude challenging the direction for mesne profits inquiry in the final decree appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direction for inquiry is discretionary power under O.20 r.12, not adjudication of controversy between parties; no party aggrieved by it.

holdings.text: The direction in the preliminary decree for mesne profits inquiry does not operate as res judicata.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not based on decision of any matter in controversy between parties but exercise of discretionary power under O.20 r.12.

holdings.text: The judgment-debtor is not estopped from raising the contention against liability for mesne profits beyond three years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conduct did not amount to consent or concession on legal limit under O.20 r.12.

anchor.surface_text: It is urged before us for the appellant that the High Court was in error in not allowing the appellant to have raised the objection based on the provisions of O .20, r. 12, C.P.C. We agree with this contention. The question sought to be raised was a pure question of law

We therefore allow the appeal with costs of this Court, set aside the decree of the Court below and remand the case to the High Court to determine afresh the quantum of mesne profits up to March 7, 1941, when the three years from the decree of the High Court expired

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was in error in not allowing the appellant to urge this additional ground before it. The main point for determination in this appeal is whether mesne profits could be awarded to the decree-holder for a period subsequent to the expiry of three years from the date of the High Courts decree, i.e., subsequent to March 7, 1941.

We therefore allow the appeal with costs of this Court, set aside the decree of the Court below and remand the case to the High Court to determine afresh the quantum of mesne profits up to March 7, 1941, when the three years from the decree of the High Court expired

anchor.surface_text: The direction in the preliminary decree cannot operate, in terms of s. 97 C.P.C. or on general principles, as res judicata for the simple reason, as stated earlier, that the direction is not based on the decision of any matter in controversy

We therefore allow the appeal with costs of this Court, set aside the decree of the Court below and remand the case to the High Court to determine afresh the quantum of mesne profits up to March 7, 1941, when the three years from the decree of the High Court expired

anchor.surface_text: It has also been urged that the judgment-debtor is estopped from raising the contention that he is not liable to pay mesne profits subsequent to March 7, 1938 in view of his conduct amounting to his consent in the award of mesne profits subsequent to March 7, 1938.
